questions.stem: What are the requirements for full entry onto the Police Station Register?

options.text: Completion of probationary period only
Successful completion of written exam, portfolio submission, critical incident test (CIT), and probationary period requirements
Only passing the written exam
Only portfolio submission

questions.explanation: Full entry onto the Police Station Register requires successful completion of all assessment components: written exam, portfolio submission, critical incident test (CIT), and completion of the 12-month probationary period with proper supervision. All components must be passed to achieve full accreditation.

references.cite: Police Station Register Arrangements 2025 — register entry
SRA PSRAS Assessment Guidelines — portfolio

questions.stem: What is required to be eligible for the duty solicitor scheme?

options.text: Only being a qualified solicitor
Full entry onto the Police Station Register and meeting ongoing registration requirements
Only completing probationary period
Only passing the written exam

questions.explanation: To be eligible for the duty solicitor scheme, you must have full entry onto the Police Station Register. This requires completing all assessment components and the probationary period. You must also maintain ongoing registration requirements to remain eligible.

references.cite: Police Station Register Arrangements 2025 — register entry
SRA PSRAS Assessment Guidelines — portfolio

questions.stem: What happens if a PSR fails to maintain registration requirements after full entry?

options.text: Nothing—registration is permanent once granted
Registration may be suspended or removed, affecting eligibility for duty solicitor scheme work
Only a warning is given
They can continue working without restrictions

questions.explanation: Registration on the Police Station Register is not permanent. If a PSR fails to maintain registration requirements (e.g., professional standards, continuing competence, or other requirements), their registration may be suspended or removed. This affects their eligibility for duty solicitor scheme work.

references.cite: Police Station Register Arrangements 2025 — register entry
SRA PSRAS Assessment Guidelines — portfolio

questions.stem: What is the key difference between probationary and full registration status?

options.text: There is no difference
Probationary PSRs are restricted from own-client work and must work under supervision; full registration allows own-client work and duty scheme eligibility
Only the length of time differs
Full registration has no restrictions

questions.explanation: Probationary PSRs are restricted from own-client work and must work under supervision during the 12-month probationary period. Full registration removes these restrictions and allows both own-client work and eligibility for the duty solicitor scheme. Full registration also requires successful completion of all assessment components.

references.cite: Police Station Register Arrangements 2025 — register entry
SRA PSRAS Assessment Guidelines — portfolio

questions.stem: A PSR has completed their probationary period but failed the CIT. What is their registration status?

options.text: They have full registration automatically
They remain on probationary status until all assessment components (including CIT) are successfully completed
They can work independently despite failing CIT
They are removed from the register

questions.explanation: All assessment components must be successfully completed for full registration. If a PSR completes the probationary period but fails any component (written exam, portfolio, or CIT), they remain on probationary status until all components are passed. Full registration requires successful completion of all requirements.

references.cite: Police Station Register Arrangements 2025 — register entry
SRA PSRAS Assessment Guidelines — portfolio
